data.heading: Introduction
data.text:
The Smart Waste Management & Recycling System (SWMRS) is designed to modernize municipal waste collection, recycling tracking, and environmental awareness. Building on the Vision & Scope document from Assignment 1, this User Requirements Document captures the system’s functional and non-functional requirements based on structured elicitation interviews with key stakeholders: Collection Workers, City Administrators, and Residents.

The SWMRS aims to optimize collection routes, improve reporting efficiency, enhance citizen engagement through mobile applications, and introduce data-driven recycling incentives. This document consolidates insights gathered from simulated interviews into structured system requirements.

children.heading: Document Purpose
children.text: The purpose of this document is to specify the user requirements for the Smart Waste Management and Recycling System (SWMRS). It defines the system’s objectives, user interactions, functional and non-functional requirements, and key use cases. The document serves as a communication bridge between stakeholders, developers, and project sponsors to ensure a shared understanding of system expectations prior to implementation.

children.heading: Project Scope
children.text:
The SWMRS is designed to improve urban waste management efficiency by integrating Internet of Things (IoT) technologies, mobile systems, and data analytics. The system monitors waste bin levels in real time, optimizes collection routes, allows users to report missed pickups or illegal dumping, and rewards citizens for recycling participation. The goal is to reduce operational costs, minimize missed collections, and promote environmental sustainability.
The system will include three main interfaces:

children.heading: Mobile App (App for citizens)
children.text: The mobile application provides an intuitive interface that allows residents to actively participate in the waste management process. Users can view the real-time status of nearby bins (such as fill levels and collection schedules), report issues like missed pickups or illegal dumping, and track their recycling activities. The app also features a reward system that encourages sustainable behavior by awarding points or incentives for consistent recycling efforts. Through this platform, citizens stay informed, engaged, and empowered to contribute to a cleaner urban environment.

children.heading: Web Dashboard (for waste management staff)
children.text: The web-based dashboard serves as the central control and monitoring platform for municipal waste management staff. It displays real-time data collected from IoT-enabled bins, including fill levels, location tracking, and maintenance alerts. Staff can analyze data trends, assign optimized collection routes, and respond promptly to reported issues from citizens. The dashboard also provides tools for generating performance reports, managing operational schedules, and improving decision-making through data analytics. This interface ensures efficient coordination and resource utilization across the waste management process.

children.heading: IoT Sensors (for bins)
children.text: Each waste bin is equipped with IoT sensors capable of measuring fill levels, detecting overflow conditions, and tracking bin location via GPS. These sensors continuously transmit data to the central system through wireless communication networks. The collected information enables predictive maintenance, route optimization, and early detection of collection issues. By integrating IoT technology, the system minimizes manual monitoring, reduces operational costs, and ensures timely waste collection for improved urban cleanliness and sustainability.

children.heading: Definitions, Acronyms, and Abbreviations
children.text:
This section provides clear explanations of the key terms, acronyms, and abbreviations used throughout the Smart Waste Management and Recycling System (SWMRS) documentation. Understanding these terms ensures consistency and clarity in communication among developers, administrators, and users. (Table: User Requirement 7)


TermDescription
SWMRSSmart Waste Management and Recycling System
IoTInternet of Things
GPSGlobal Positioning System
APIApplication Programming Interface
AdminAuthorized system manager
CitizenRegistered public user of the mobile app

children.heading: Overview
children.text: The remainder of this document provides a detailed description of the system’s functionalities, user classes, system features, and analysis models. It also includes use case diagrams and specifications based on stakeholder needs identified in the Vision and Scope document.

children.heading: References
children.text:
IEEE Std 830-1998: Recommended Practice for Software Requirements Specifications

City of Kamloops Waste Collection Guidelines (2024)

TRU SENG 3130 Assignment 2 Template (Fall 2025)

data.heading: Overall Description
data.text: This section provides a high-level overview of the Smart Waste Management & Recycling System (SWMRS) and the environment in which it will operate. It describes the system’s context, user community, and major interactions with external components such as IoT bin sensors and mobile devices. It also outlines the intended operating environment, design constraints, and underlying assumptions that shape the system’s development. The goal of this section is to help readers understand how the SWMRS fits into the broader municipal waste management ecosystem and the general capabilities it will deliver before detailing specific system features and functional requirements.

children.heading: Product Perspective
children.text: SWMRS is a new, integrated system combining existing waste management operations with new IoT and mobile technologies. It will collect bin sensor data, process it in the backend, and present actionable insights to waste management teams through an interactive dashboard. The citizen-facing the system will act as the main communication channel for public users.

children.heading: Product Functions
children.text: The Smart Waste Management & Recycling System (SWMRS) provides an integrated platform that automates and optimizes the waste collection and recycling process through real-time data and user interaction. Its main functions ensure efficiency, transparency, and sustainability in municipal waste management operations.

children.heading: Real-Time Monitoring of Waste Bins
children.text: IoT sensors installed in waste and recycling bins continuously measure fill levels, temperature, and location, transmitting data to the central server for live status tracking.

children.heading: Predictive Analysis of Collection Schedules
children.text: The system uses historical and sensor data to forecast when bins will reach capacity, allowing proactive scheduling to prevent overflow and optimize resource use.

children.heading: Automatic Route Optimization for Waste Trucks
children.text: Dynamic algorithms generate the most efficient collection routes based on bin fill data, vehicle location, and traffic conditions, reducing fuel consumption and time.

children.heading: Citizen Issue Reporting and Missed Collection Alerts
children.text: Residents can report issues such as missed pickups, contamination, or obstructed bins via the mobile app, and receive real-time notifications about collection status.

children.heading: Recycling Reward Tracking and Redemption
children.text: A resident-facing rewards module tracks individual recycling activity, awards points for participation, and enables users to view and redeem rewards through their app dashboard.

children.heading: Administrative Control and Data Analytics Dashboard
children.text: City administrators can monitor fleet operations, sensor health, and collection performance through a secure web dashboard, generating customized analytical and compliance reports.

children.heading: User Classes and Characteristics
children.text: he Smart Waste Management & Recycling System (SWMRS) serves multiple user groups across municipal operations, residents, and external partners. Each user class interacts with the system through specific interfaces and privileges suited to their role. Direct users access the system’s operational and citizen-facing functions, while indirect users engage through integration or support activities. Disfavored users represent potential misuse or threats that the system must protect against through authentication and security controls.

children.heading: User Classes and Profiles
children.text:
User ClassTypeRole / Description
Collection Worker (Driver)Direct / FavoredOperates collection vehicles, follows assigned optimized routes, confirms pickups (timestamp, GPS, photo), completes pre-trip checklist, and reports skipped or problematic pickups.
Route SupervisorDirect / FavoredMonitors routes and driver performance, approves or investigates skipped pickups, reassigns tasks, and reviews incident reports and communications with residents.
City Administrator / Fleet ManagerDirect / FavoredConfigures route optimization and policy rules, manages user roles and fleets, monitors KPIs via dashboards, and runs compliance and audit reports.
Resident (Citizen App User)Direct / FavoredReports missed pickups, receives collection notifications, tracks recycling progress, earns and redeems reward points through the mobile app.
Maintenance TechnicianIndirect / FavoredReceives IoT sensor health alerts, manages maintenance tickets, and performs repairs or replacements of sensors and communication devices.
Rewards Partner (Local Business / Vendor)Indirect / FavoredProvides discounts or vouchers for the rewards program, validates redemptions, and reconciles offers with the city or system operator.
Unauthorized Public User / Malicious ActorIndirect / DisfavoredAttempts unauthorized access or data tampering; system must detect, block, and log such activities for audit and security monitoring.
Illegal Dumpers / ScavengersIndirect / DisfavoredIndividuals attempting to dump waste illegally or tamper with bins; system flags repeated incidents using sensor or CCTV data for administrative action.

children.heading: System Actors
children.text: The Smart Waste Management & Recycling System (SWMRS) interacts with both human and non-human actors. Human actors directly operate or manage system functions, while non-human actors include integrated devices, APIs, and automated services that provide essential data and automation.

children.heading: Human Actors
children.text:
ActorDescription
Driver (Collection Worker)Primary actor responsible for executing waste pickups, confirming bin collection, and reporting route incidents through the driver interface.
Route SupervisorOversees daily operations, reviews driver activity, handles exceptions such as missed pickups, and manages route adjustments.
City Administrator / Fleet ManagerConfigures system parameters, manages user roles, monitors fleet performance, and generates analytical or compliance reports.
ResidentEngages with the citizen app to report missed pickups or contamination, track recycling rewards, and receive real-time notifications.

children.heading: Non-Human Actors
children.text:
ActorDescription
IoT Bin SensorSends real-time fill-level, location, and health data to the central server, triggering collection or maintenance events as needed.
Vehicle Telematics / GPS ServiceStreams truck position, route progress, speed, and vehicle telemetry data to the system for live monitoring and analytics.
Traffic Data APIExternal data provider that supplies live and historical traffic information used by the route optimization engine.
Scheduled Trigger / Cron JobAutomated temporal actor that performs periodic system tasks such as nightly data aggregation, re-optimization, and report generation.
Rewards Payment / Voucher GatewayExternal payment or vendor system that validates and processes reward redemptions and returns confirmation data.
Ticketing / Maintenance SystemIntegrated system that manages maintenance tickets and records sensor repairs or replacements, either internally or through third-party services.

children.heading: Main Use Cases
children.text:
Use Case

Description

Primary Actor

Secondary Actors

UC-01 – Optimize Collection Route

Compute efficient collection routes using bin fill-levels, vehicle capacities, and traffic; generate driver assignments.

Route Optimization Service or City Administrator

IoT Bin Sensor, Vehicle Telematics, Traffic Data API, Driver

UC-02 – View Live Map & Assets

Show real-time map of trucks, routes, and monitored bins with status overlays.

City Administrator or Fleet Manager

Vehicle Telematics, IoT Bin Sensor, Driver

UC-03 – Complete Pickup / Confirm Collection

Driver confirms pickup; system records GPS, timestamp, and optional photo as proof of service.

Driver

Resident (if they reported/are notified), Vehicle Telematics, Backend Audit Service

UC-04 – Report Missed Pickup / Issue

Resident or Driver files a location-specific complaint (missed pickup, contamination) with optional photo and priority.

Resident or Driver

Route Supervisor, Admin (for escalations), Ticketing System

UC-05 – Offline Route Access & Sync

Driver loads last assigned route offline, works without connectivity, then syncs completed pickups and notes when online.

Driver

Backend Sync Service, Admin

UC-06 – Pre-Trip Vehicle Checklist

Driver completes mandatory safety and equipment checklist before route start; checklist is logged and audited.

Driver

Fleet Manager, Audit Log Service

UC-07 – Sensor Health Monitoring

System monitors telemetry for sensor anomalies such as no data transmission, battery low, unrealistic fill levels, and raises maintenance tickets.

Monitoring Service (system)

Maintenance Technician, Ticketing System, Admin

UC-08 – Track & Redeem Recycling Rewards

Resident views points/score, redeems rewards or vouchers, and sees redemption history.

Resident

Rewards Gateway, Rewards Partner, Admin

children.heading: Use Cases and Models
children.text: This section defines the key interactions between system actors and the Smart Waste Management & Recycling System (SWMRS). Each use case represents a goal-oriented activity performed by a user or external system to achieve a specific function. Use cases help clarify system boundaries, actor responsibilities, and the flow of data within the waste management ecosystem. (Figure: User Requirements-28_1_UserCaseDiagram)

children.heading: UC-001 — Optimize Collection Route
children.text:
Use Case ID and Name

UC-001 — Optimize Collection Route

Author and Date Created

Emerson Tavera — 2025-10-19

Primary Actor

Route Optimization Service (automated) 

City Administrator (manual trigger)

Secondary Actors

Collection Worker (Driver)

 IoT Bin Sensor

Vehicle Telematics Service

Traffic Data API

Scheduled Trigger

Description

Generate optimized collection routes for available trucks using bin fill-levels, vehicle capacity, traffic, and priority zones. Outcome: route assignments stored, pushed to drivers, and recorded with audit entries.

Trigger

Scheduled periodic trigger (e.g., hourly or nightly full-reoptimize).

Event-driven trigger (bin fill-level ≥ configured threshold).

Manual admin request (on-demand re-run).

Preconditions

Latest bin telemetry (fill-level + timestamp) is available for considered bins.

Vehicle availability and capacities are known (fleet registry up-to-date).

Optimization parameters are defined (min-fill threshold, priority zones, time windows, max route duration, cost function).

Sensor health check has run and unhealthy sensors are flagged/excluded or marked for conservative handling.

Postconditions

Success

Store updated routes with audit metadata (actor, timestamp, data source, reason).

Deliver updated routes to assigned drivers — pushed immediately or queued for offline sync.

Record optimization metrics (distance, ETA, fuel/time estimate) to improve route efficiency over time.

Notify supervisors per configuration.

If failed, the system generates provisional routes with a confidence score and notes on any data issues, then logs an audit record and notifies the admin or supervisor.

children.heading: Alternative Flow 1
children.text: This flow handles cases where the system cannot access live traffic data. Cached, historical, or default travel times are used instead, and the optimization run is marked as degraded. (Figure: User Requirements-31_1_OptimizeCollectionRoute_AlternativeFlow1)

children.heading: Alternative Flow 2
children.text:
This flow occurs when the system is configured to require supervisor review before finalizing routes. Proposed routes are sent for approval, and optimization resumes after feedback or confirmation.

(Figure: User Requirements-32_1_OptimizeCollectionRoute_AlternativeFlow2)

children.heading: Alternative Flow 3
children.text: If the optimizer finds no feasible routes, generate split routes, flag the capacity shortage to the supervisor, and (optionally) relax thresholds and re-run per admin policy. (Figure: User Requirements-33_1 OptimizeCollectionRoute_AlternativeFlow3)

children.heading: Exceptions, Priority and Assumptions
children.text:
Exceptions

Sensor data stale/missing: If required sensor data older than 24 hours, exclude those bins and log warning (continue optimization).

Optimization engine or DB failure: Abort route update, retain prior routes, alert admins, and log failure.

Push to device fails: If driver device offline, mark route pending and schedule retry at next sync; if critical, notify supervisor.

Priority

High

Business Rules

BR-001, BR-002, BR-003, BR-004

Assumptions

Sensors and telematics send accurate timestamps and identifiers.

Drivers carry compatible devices and will sync when connectivity restored

Other information

Quality: Target route calculation latency to be defined in NFRs (example: < 60s for a city sub-region).
Failure policy: On optimization engine failure, no partial route updates are pushed. Prior routes remain active until replacement routes are verified and audited.

children.heading: UC-002 — Report Missed Pickup / Issue (Resident)
children.text:
Use Case ID and Name

UC-002 — Report Missed Pickup / Issue (Resident)

Author and Date Created

Emerson Tavera — 2025-10-19

Primary Actor

Resident (via mobile app)

Secondary Actors

Route Supervisor (human), City Administrator (for escalations), Vehicle Telematics Service (for presence verification), Maintenance/Ticketing System (for hardware issues), Notification Service

Description

A resident uses the SWMRS mobile app to report an issue for a specific address (e.g., missed pickup, obstruction, contamination, or damaged bin). The system collects structured details (issue type, address/bin ID, description), optional media (photos/videos), and automatic metadata (GPS, timestamp, reporter ID). It stores the report, notifies the appropriate supervisor queue, and triggers follow-up actions such as acknowledgment, investigation, rerouting, or maintenance according to business rules and SLAs.

Trigger

The resident opens the SWMRS mobile app and selects “Report Issue” for their address, or taps a “Report” button from a missed-pickup notification.

Preconditions

PRE-1. Resident is authenticated in the app (unless anonymous reporting is allowed by policy).
PRE-2. Resident account is linked to an address and bin ID (or can be selected manually).
PRE-3. Device has enough storage for optional media and can capture or input location data (GPS or manual address).
PRE-4. Supervisor queue service is available to accept new reports (if not, system will queue locally).

Postconditions

POST-1. Report is stored with a unique Report ID, reporter ID (or anonymous flag), timestamp, GPS/address, issue type, description, and any media or references.
POST-2. Report is placed in the appropriate supervisor queue, and an acknowledgment is sent to the resident within the defined SLA.
POST-3. If immediate action is needed, a follow-up task (reroute, return pickup, maintenance) is created and linked to the report.

children.heading: Alternative Flow 1
children.text: Anonymous Report Allowed: If local policy allows, the resident can submit a report without signing in. The system collects minimal contact information (optional), stores the report as anonymous, and limits communication to public status updates. (Figure Figure User Requirements-37_1:  ReportMissedPickup_AlternativeFlow1)

children.heading: Alternative Flow 2
children.text: Report from Missed-Pickup Notification: The resident taps “Report” from a missed-pickup alert. The issue type and timestamp are prefilled, and the system may check vehicle telemetry for presence verification before submission. (Figure:  User Requirements-38_1_ReportMissedPickup_AlternativeFlow2)

children.heading: Alternative Flow 3
children.text: Resident Selects Different Address/Bin: If the suggested address or bin is incorrect, the resident can select or manually enter another address. The system validates the mapping and continues with the selected location. (Figure:  User Requirements-39_1_ReportMissedPickup_AlternativeFlow3)

children.heading: Exceptions, Priority and Assumptions
children.text:
Exceptions

Media upload fails: The report is stored with a media placeholder; upload retries automatically once connectivity returns.
Address-to-bin mapping missing or ambiguous: The system prompts for manual selection; if unresolved, the report is flagged as “unverified.”
Supervisor queue unavailable: The system queues the report and retries routing; acknowledgment still sent to resident.
Duplicate report detected: The system warns the resident and offers to attach media to an existing open report.

Priority

High: impacts resident satisfaction and service-level performance.

Business Rules

BR-005. Missed-pickup reports must be acknowledged within the SLA.
BR-006. Attached photos are part of the audit log.
BR-007. Driver photo evidence may reclassify issue type (e.g., “Skipped — Contamination”).
BR-003. All actions must be auditable.

Assumptions

Resident address–bin mappings are accurate.
GPS or manual location input is sufficient.
Supervisors act on reports within SLA.

Other Information

SLA Compliance: The system must send acknowledgment within SLA (e.g., 24h) and update the resident on progress and resolution.
Offline Mode: Reports can be queued offline and auto-synced when connectivity returns.
Auditability: All supervisor and system actions are logged with timestamps.
Failure Policy: In case of systemic failure, the app shows a user-friendly error and retry behavior.

children.heading: UC-003 — Track & Redeem Recycling Rewards
children.text:
Use Case ID and Name

UC-003 — Track & Redeem Recycling Rewards

Author and Date Created

Emerson Tavera — 2025-10-19

Primary Actor

Resident

Secondary Actor

Rewards Gateway (vendor API), City Administrator (configures rewards), IoT Bin Sensor (validates collections), Audit Log Service

Description

Resident monitors their recycling performance, earns points for validated collections, browses a rewards catalog, and redeems rewards. The system ensures collection events are verified before awarding points and coordinates redemption with reward providers.

Trigger

Resident opens the Rewards section in the app or receives a push notification of awarded points and selects a reward to redeem.

Preconditions

Resident has a verified account linked to an address and bin. Collection events for the resident's bin are validated. Rewards catalog contains at least one active reward.

Postconditions

Resident points balance is updated. If a reward is redeemed, vendor is notified and the redemption is logged. Resident receives confirmation with redemption details or voucher.

children.heading: Alternative Flow 1
children.text: Insufficient points : A path describing what happens when a resident attempts to redeem a reward but does not have enough points. The system notifies the resident, offers alternative rewards, partial redemption options, or allows cancellation. (Figure: User Requirements-43_1_TrackRedemRecyclingRewards_AlternativeFlow1)

children.heading: Alternative Flow 2
children.text: Points pending validation: A path describing the situation where the residents’ points are not yet validated. The system blocks redemption, displays pending status, shows expected validation date, and optionally allows requesting manual intervention. (Figure: User Requirements-44_1_TrackRedemRecyclingRewards_AlternativeFlow2)

children.heading: Exceptions, Priority and Assumptions
children.text:
Exceptions

Vendor or Gateway failure during redemption triggers rollback and notification. Duplicate redemption attempts are detected and prevented.

Priority

Medium

Business Rules

BR-008, BR-009, BR-010

Assumptions

Vendors support API or voucher-based redemptions. Points calculations depend only on validated pickups.

Other Information

Security: high-value redemptions may require MFA. Redemptions are atomic; points debit and vendor confirmation succeed or are rolled back. Rewards history is treated as personal data and retained per policy.

children.heading: Constraints
children.text: The Smart Waste Management & Recycling System (SWMRS) must operate within several technical, regulatory, and environmental limitations. These constraints define the boundaries and conditions that influence system design, implementation, and deployment.

children.heading: Regulatory Compliance
children.text: The system must adhere to all city waste management policies, environmental regulations, and data privacy laws governing municipal digital systems. Any updates to these policies must be reflected in future software revisions.

children.heading: Connectivity Limitations
children.text: Due to limited mobile data coverage in certain areas, the system must support offline functionality for drivers and field workers, allowing data to be stored locally and synchronized when connectivity is restored.

children.heading: System Integration Requirements
children.text: The SWMRS must integrate seamlessly with existing municipal platforms, such as asset management or ticketing systems. This may require API alignment and data format compatibility to ensure smooth information exchange between systems.

children.heading: Assumptions and Dependencies
children.text: The development and operation of the Smart Waste Management & Recycling System (SWMRS) rely on several assumptions about the environment, users, and technology, as well as dependencies on external systems and factors outside the project team’s direct control.

children.heading: User Competency
children.text: It is assumed that all direct users (drivers, supervisors, administrators, and residents) have basic digital literacy and are capable of using the mobile or web interfaces provided by the system.

children.heading: Sensor Reliability
children.text: IoT bin sensors are assumed to function according to manufacturer specifications, reporting accurate fill levels, location, and status data consistently.

children.heading: Data Availability
children.text: The system assumes continuous access to required external data, such as traffic updates from the Traffic Data API, for route optimization.

children.heading: Device Compatibility
children.text: Users are assumed to access the system using supported devices (smartphones, tablets, or web-enabled computers) with up-to-date operating systems and browsers.

children.heading: External APIs and Services
children.text: SWMRS depends on external services such as traffic data providers, payment gateways, and municipal ticketing systems for certain features to function correctly.

children.heading: Network and Connectivity
children.text: The system relies on sufficient network infrastructure (cellular or Wi-Fi) for real-time monitoring, notifications, and synchronization. Offline modes mitigate temporary connectivity issues but assume eventual network access.

children.heading: Legal and Regulatory Environment
children.text: The system’s operation depends on compliance with existing municipal policies, environmental regulations, and privacy laws. Changes in these regulations may necessitate updates to SWMRS functionality.

attrValues._a136e4be-cb82-4459-a4f5-2b5545a2102e: Salam, Emer and Dianna, Thompson Rivers University, t00697855@mytru.ca
